wikipedia_page.main: Tamar Yellin (born 1963) is an author and teacher who lives in Yorkshire. Her first novel, The Genizah at the House of Shepher, won the 2007 Sami Rohr Prize for Jewish Literature.

link_mentions.page: Sami Rohr Prize for Jewish Literature
response: *  The Genizah at the House of Shepher, by Tamar Yellin
* Tamar Yellin, Genizah at the House of Shepher (Toby Press)

In 2007, Yitzhak Yakov's granddaughter, English author Tamar Yellin, won the Sami Rohr Prize, a Jewish literary prize, for her novel "The Genizah at the House of Shepher", a fictitious tale whose origin lies in the true tales of the Yellin family and on letters and documents found in the attic of Yitzhak Yakov Yellin's house in Jerusalem.

link_mentions.page: History of the Jews in Leeds
response: Tamar Yellin (born 1963) is a Leeds-born and raised writer who studied Hebrew and Arabic at Oxford. Prizes include winner 2007 Sami Rohr Prize. She has taken fellowships at Leeds University and lives in Yorkshire; her work explores Jewish life and culture.
Tamar Yellin novelist, studied Hebrew and Arabic at Oxford (see Arts and entertainment, above).
Tamar Yellin (see Arts and entertainment, above) has taken fellowships at Leeds University.
